Zhu Daosheng, originally surnamed Wei, was a person from Julu who lived in Pengcheng.
His family had served in official positions for generations, and his father was the magistrate of Guangqi, known as a good person in the village.
Daosheng was exceptionally intelligent and wise from a young age, like a divine being.
His father knew he was no ordinary vessel and loved him, regarding him as extraordinary. Later, he met the monk Zhu Fatai and thus changed his secular surname to take refuge and receive teachings.
Having entered the Dharma gate, his extraordinary thoughts were outstanding. He pondered the meaning of the scriptures and immediately understood by himself.

Therefore, in his years of studying, he ascended the lecture seat and spoke and debated questions. His words were clear like pearls and jade. Even the elders of the monastic community and famous scholars of the time all worried about being defeated in words and exhausted in argumentation, not daring to respond or resist.
When he reached the age of full ordination, his discernment became increasingly profound. His nature and conduct were alert, and his spirit was pure and dignified.
When he first entered Mount Lu, he secluded himself for seven years to pursue his aspirations.

He always considered wisdom and understanding to be the foundation for entering the Way, so he delved into the scriptures and pondered various treatises, traveling thousands of miles in pursuit of the Dharma, not wearying of the hardships.
Later, he traveled to Chang'an with Huiye and Huiyan to study under Master KumÄrajÄ«va.
The monks in Guanzhong all considered him to be spiritually awakened.
Later, he returned to the capital and stayed at Qingyuan Temple.
The temple was established by Empress Chu of the Jin Dynasty, Gongsi. It was originally a place where indigo was grown, hence its name.
Since Sengzhao was a Dharma master of the time, he was invited to reside there.
Emperor Taizu Wenhuang of the Song Dynasty deeply admired and respected him.
Later, Emperor Taizu held a gathering and the emperor himself sat with the assembly on the ground mats. After the meal, the assembly suspected it was getting late, but the emperor said:
It's only noon.
Sengzhao said:
The sun is shining in the sky, and the emperor says it's only noon. How can it not be noon?
He then took the bowl and ate, and the entire assembly followed suit, all admiring his ability to hit the mark.
Wang Hong, Fan Tai, and Yan Yan all admired his teachings and followed him to inquire about the Way.
Since Sheng had been contemplating for a long time, he penetrated the meaning beyond the words and sighed:
The symbols are used to convey the meaning, but once the meaning is understood, the symbols are forgotten.
Words are used to express the principles, but once the principles are understood, the words are put to rest.
Since the scriptures first came to the East, the translators faced many obstacles, and they mostly adhered to the literal meaning, rarely seeing the perfect meaning.
If one forgets the trap to catch the fish, only then can one speak of the Way.
Thereupon, he examined the true and the mundane, and pondered cause and effect, and established good deeds do not receive retribution and sudden enlightenment to become a Buddha.

He also wrote the Treatise on the Two Truths, the Treatise on Buddha-nature Being Present, the Treatise on the Formless DharmakÄya, the Treatise on the Buddha Having No Pure Land, the Treatise on the Existence of Conditions, and others, which enveloped the old teachings with wonderful and profound meanings.
However, those who adhered to the texts often gave rise to resentment and jealousy, and the sounds of acceptance and rejection arose in competition.

Moreover, the six-fascicle Nirvana Sutra had already arrived in the capital. Sengrui analyzed the principles of the sutra and penetrated its profound meanings. He then expounded that all icchantikas will attain Buddhahood.
At that time, the full version had not yet been transmitted. His solitary insight arose first, and his unique view offended the crowd.
Therefore, the old scholars considered it a heretical teaching, and their resentment intensified. They finally exposed him to the great assembly, expelled him.
Sengrui made a vow in the great assembly with a composed countenance:
If what I say goes against the meaning of the sutra, I request that I will immediately show signs of severe illness in this very life;
If it does not contradict the true characteristics, I wish that at the time of giving up my life, I will be seated on a lion's seat.
After saying this, he shook his sleeves and left.
He first went to Tiger Hill in Wu, and in a few days, he had several hundred students.

In the summer of that year, thunder shook the Buddha hall in Qingyuan, and a dragon ascended to the heavens, its light and shadow on the western wall. The name of the temple was changed to Dragon Light.
At that time, people sighed and said:
Since the dragon has already left, [Luan] will surely leave.
Soon after, he left traces on Mount Lu, disappearing into the mountain peaks. The monks in the mountain all respected and served him.

Later, the complete text of the Nirvana Sutra arrived in Nanjing, and it indeed said that all icchantikas have Buddha-nature, which was in agreement with what he had said before, like a matching tally.

After being born, he obtained this sutra and immediately lectured on it. In the eleventh month of winter in the eleventh year of the Yuanjia era of the Song dynasty, on a gengzi day, he ascended the Dharma seat at the hermitage on Mount Lu. His countenance was open and bright, and his virtuous voice was sharp and clear. He debated several times, exhausting the principles and reaching the subtleties.
The audience of observers and listeners were all enlightened and delighted.

At the end of the Dharma session, he suddenly saw the horsetail whisk fall with a flurry. He sat upright with a proper countenance, leaned on the desk, and passed away. His complexion did not change, as if he had entered concentration.
Monks and laypeople sighed in amazement, and those far and near wept sorrowfully.
Then the monks in the capital city felt ashamed and remorseful, and they followed and believed in him.
His spiritual discernment was so profound that the auspicious signs were like this.
He was then buried on the hill of Mount Lu.
At first, Sheng, together with Master Rui, Yan, and Guan, were classmates and equally famous. Therefore, people of the time commented:
Sheng and Rui's talent was born from heaven, Yan and Guan's was acquired through learning. Hui and Yi advanced through hard work, Kou and Yuan were blocked.
Only Sengsheng and Dao'an were given the title of Heavenly Truth, thus standing out among the many scholars.
At first, Sengzhao of Guanzhong first commented on the Vimalakirti Sutra.
The world all enjoyed and savored it.
Sengsheng then further developed the profound meaning, revealing new and different interpretations of various sutras, which the world all treasured.
Wang Mi compared Sengsheng to Guo Linzong, and thus wrote a biography for him, praising his remaining virtues.
At that time, people considered Sengsheng's claim that icchantikas can attain Buddhahood to be well-founded.
The sudden enlightenment and non-acceptance of retribution, etc., were also considered to be groundbreaking at the time.
Emperor Taizu of the Song Dynasty once discussed the meaning of sudden enlightenment with Sengsheng, and monks such as Sengbi all raised huge objections.
The Emperor said:
If the deceased could be revived, how could he be defeated by you all?

Later, there was also a monk named Bao Lin at Longguang Temple. He first studied in Chang'an and later inherited Sengsheng's various interpretations. At that time, people called him Sengsheng of the Xuan School.
He wrote the Nirvana Commentary, Annotation on the Treatise on Different Doctrines, Proclamation to the Demons, and other works.
Fa Bao, a disciple of Lin, also studied both Buddhism and non-Buddhist teachings. He wrote the Treatise on the Mind after the Diamond Sutra and other works, also inheriting Seng's teachings.
In recent times, there was also Shi Hui Sheng, who also stayed at Longguang Temple.
He ate vegetarian food, was good at various sutras, and was also skilled in cursive calligraphy.
People of the time, because of staying in the same temple, called him the Great and Small Two Shengs.
Shi Hui Rui, a monk from Jizhou,
left home at a young age and upheld strict discipline. He often traveled to study.
While traveling in the western border of Shu, he was captured and made to herd sheep.
A merchant who had faith and respect saw him and found it strange. Suspecting he was a monk, he asked about the meaning of the sutras, and there was nothing he did not thoroughly understand.
The merchant then redeemed him with gold. After returning, he put on dyed robes again, and his diligent study became even more intense.
He traveled to various countries and eventually reached South India.
He was well-versed in the sounds, translations, and meanings of different languages and customs.
Later, he rested at Mount Lu.

He then entered the capital and followed Master KumÄrajÄ«va to study. Later, he went to the capital and lectured on various sÅ«tras. His explanations were all profound and his principles were in perfect accord.
The General of the Song Dynasty, Prince of Pengcheng, asked him to be his teacher. After repeated requests, he finally agreed.
The prince invited him to the residence to receive the precepts. Rui said:
The rules say that a teacher comes to learn, not to teach others.
The prince was greatly ashamed and then entered the temple to pay homage and respectfully accept the precepts. Later, he offered a sable fur coat to Rui.
Rui did not wear it, but always sat on it.
The prince secretly ordered his attendants to buy it, offering three hundred thousand coins.
Rui said:
Although it is not what I would wear, since it is what the great king has given, I will use it out of courtesy.
Xie Lingyun of Chenjun was devoted to Buddhist principles and had a deep understanding of many foreign languages.

He then consulted with Huiyuan on the various characters in the sutras, as well as the different meanings of the various sounds, and composed the Fourteen Sounds and Explanations to clearly list the Sanskrit and Chinese characters, making the texts have a basis.
Huiyuan passed away in the Yuanjia era of the Song dynasty at the age of eighty-five.
Shi Huiyan, Shi Huiyan, whose surname was Fan, was a person from Yuzhou.
At the age of twelve, he became a student and was well-versed in poetry and books. At sixteen, he left home and further refined the Buddhist principles.
By the time he was an adult, his learning had penetrated the scriptures, and his reputation spread far and wide, with his teachings reaching distant lands.
Hearing that Master KumÄrajÄ«va was in Guanzhong, he followed him to study and inquired about the correct sounds and meanings, hearing many different things.
Later, he returned to the capital and stayed at Dong'an Temple.
Emperor Gaozu of the Song dynasty had known and respected him for a long time.
Later, Emperor Gaozu attacked Chang'an.
He insisted on going with them, Yan said:
Although this journey of yours is to punish crimes and console the people, I am a person outside of affairs and dare not accept the order.
The emperor insisted, and he finally went.
When Emperor Wen was in power, his feelings of fondness were even more intimate, and every time he saw [Yan] he praised and asked about Buddhism.

Previously, the emperor did not greatly revere and believe in [Buddhism], but in the 12th year of the Yuanjia era, the Capital Prefect Xiao Mo presented a memorial requesting to establish temples and cast Buddha images.
The emperor then discussed it with the Palace Attendant He Shangzhi, the Court of Imperial Treasuries Director Yang Xuanbao, and others, and said to Shangzhi:

Since I was young, I have not read many scriptures, and nowadays I have even less time. I have not yet discerned the causes and effects of the three periods of existence, and I dare not establish differences, precisely because you are the most outstanding among your contemporaries and I respect and believe in what you do.

Fan Tai and Xie Lingyun often said that the texts of the Six Classics are originally for governing the people, but if one seeks the true profundity of the spiritual nature, how can one not take the Buddhist scriptures as a guide?

Recently, I have seen Yan Ying's Treatise on Promoting the Nature and Zong Bing's Treatise on the Difficulty of Distinguishing Black and White, which clearly show the vastness of Buddhism, and are especially famous and reasonable, enough to inspire people's minds.
If it could be made so that all within the realm are devoted to this transformation, then I would sit and bring about a peaceful world, what more could I ask for?
Recently, Xiao Mo's request for a decree has not yet fully passed through, so I am sending it to you to add or subtract from it.
If there is a way to stop excessive indulgence without harming the promotion of Buddhism, then I will issue an order.
Shang Zhi replied:
The ignorant masses often do not believe in the Dharma. As for me, being mediocre and incompetent, I alone uphold my foolish diligence. I fear that my shortcomings will offend the great teaching.
Now I am even more honored with praise and encouragement, which I dare not accept.
As for the eminent figures of previous generations, they did not disappoint the imperial edict.
The central court is far away, and it is difficult to know everything.

Since crossing the river, there were Wang Dao, Zhou Yi, Yu Liang, Wang Meng, Xie Shang, Xi Chao, Wang Tan, Wang Gong, Wang Mi, Guo Wen, Xie Fu, Dai Kui, Xu Xun, and the deceased Gaozu's brothers, Wang Yuanlin's siblings, Fan Wang, Sun Shu, Zhang Xuan, and Yin Yi, either as prime ministers or as prominent figures in human affairs, either immersed in the realm of immortals, or living in seclusion in the clouds and mist, all of whom dedicated their minds to taking refuge and placed their hearts in revering and believing.
Among them, Lan, Hu, Kai, Qian, Yuan, Dun, Chong, and Sui all imitated the Yellow Emperor and the Central Emperor, or were extraordinary people.

In recent times, both monastics and laypeople have discussed this matter in this way. If we were to comprehensively list the extraordinary talents and virtues of those from China and the West, from the Han and Wei dynasties, how could we possibly speak of them all?
Master Huiyuan once said:
The teachings of Buddhism are unobstructed.
Adapting to the Way is indeed the source of the teachings, but benefiting the secular world is also an important task.
I have secretly examined this statement, and it accords with the profound truth.
Why is this so?
If every household upholds the precepts, then a country will cease to need punishments.
Therefore, when Master BuddhajÄ«va arrived in Zhao, the two Shi brothers reduced their cruelty;
when the spiritual pagoda emitted light, Fu Jian lessened his brutality.
Therefore, the spiritual way assists the teachings, and this has its origins.
However, what Xiao Mo has brought up is not entirely incorrect.

But the harm to the Buddhist teachings and the secular world is fundamentally in the unpracticed monks and nuns, and it is difficult to distinguish their emotions and appearances, and it is not easy to remove them.
Although gold, bronze, earth, and wood are deeply wasteful, they must be the basis for meritorious deeds, and it is difficult to suddenly cut them off.
I have been pondering this matter, and it is difficult to find a solution. Today, hearing your virtuous words, I am truly deeply at ease.
Yang Xuanbao then said:
This discussion is indeed beyond the realm of humans and gods. How could it be suitable for a subject like me?
I am afraid that the methods of raising strong troops discussed by Qin and Chu, and the plans for conquest and annexation by Sun and Wu, will not be found here.
The Emperor said:
This is not a tool for the Warring States period, it is exactly as you say.
Shang Zhi said:
If you honor those who hide their talents and avoid office, then soldiers will be lazy. If you value benevolence and virtue, then the fighting spirit will decline.
If you take Sun and Wu as your goal, and are only concerned with conquest and annexation, then you will not find the way of Yao and Shun. Is it only the Buddhist teachings that are like this?
The Emperor was delighted and said:
The Buddhist order has you, just as the Confucian school had Zigong. So-called bad words do not enter the ears.
From then on, the Emperor's faith was established. He began to pay attention to Buddhist scriptures.
He also met with Yan and Guan, and discussed the principles of the Way with them.

At that time, Yan Yan-zhi wrote the Discernment of Consciousness and the Examination of Discourses, the Emperor ordered Yan to debate their similarities and differences. They went back and forth all day, and the Emperor laughed and said:
You gentlemen today, are not ashamed of Zhi and Xu.
Yan later wrote the Treatise on Non-arising and Non-ceasing and the Abridged Annotations on Laozi, etc.
He Cheng-tian of the Eastern Sea was known for his vast knowledge, so he asked Yan about the calendar used in the Buddha's country.
Yan said:

In India, at the summer solstice, the sun is directly overhead with no shadow, which is called the center of the heavens. Among the five elements, earth is the virtue. Yellow is the predominant color, and five is the predominant number. Eight inches is one foot. Ten liang is equivalent to twelve liang in this land. The month of Jian and Chen is the beginning of the year.

As for the investigation and calculation of solar and lunar eclipses, the observation of the sun's position, and the measurement of the sun's light, their methods are very detailed. The calculation of the stars' positions and the years are all based on systematic rules.
Chengtian had nothing to say in response.

Because of your power in propagating the sutra, you will surely see the Buddha.
Yan died at Dong'an Temple in the 20th year of the Yuanjia era of the Song dynasty, at the age of 81.
The emperor issued a decree, saying:
Master Yan's knowledge was profound and far-reaching, and he was a teacher of the Way. He suddenly passed away, and I am deeply saddened.
50 bolts of cloth.
Yan's disciple Fazhi had a divine understanding since childhood.
At the age of 24, he went to Jiangling and met Master Ya lecturing. He debated with him several times, and Ya had no ground to respond.
Ya looked around the audience and said:
This young man has eloquently composed chapters.
Fazhi laughed and said:
Now the style has changed and become elegant.
Thus, his reputation spread throughout Chu and Ying, and his praise reached the capital and Wu.
He was good at the Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra and the Mahayana and Hinayana Abhidharma.
4 Shi Huiguan, Shi Huiguan, whose surname was Cui, was a person from Qinghe.
At the age of ten, he was already known for his extensive knowledge. He left home at a young age and traveled to study. Later, he visited Mount Lu and consulted with Huiyuan.
When he heard that Master KumÄrajÄ«va had entered the Pass, he went from the south to the north to investigate the similarities and differences, and carefully discuss the new and old teachings.
His spiritual temperament was elegant and refined, and his thoughts penetrated the profound and subtle.
People of the time praised him, saying:
If it comes to understanding the meaning, then Sengrui and Sengzhao are the leaders. If it comes to precision and difficulty, then Huiguan and Sengzhao are the best.
He then wrote the Preface to the Essential Meaning of the Lotus Sutra to show to KumÄrajÄ«va. KumÄrajÄ«va said:
Good man, your discussion is very wonderful. You should go south to the area between the Jiang and Han rivers when you are young, and be good at promoting and spreading the teachings.
After KumÄrajÄ«va passed away, he went south to Jingzhou.

Sima Xu, the general of the state, respected and valued him very much. He established Gao Kui Temple for him, causing half of the people in Jing and Chu who had turned to evil to return to righteousness.
When Emperor Wu of the Song marched south and arrived in Jiangling, he met with Guan and treated him with utmost sincerity, just as before.
He then ordered him to accompany the Prince of Xichong, who was none other than Emperor Wen.
Guan soon returned to the capital and stayed at Daochang Temple.

As Guan was already well-versed in Buddhist principles and had studied Laozi and Zhuangzi, and was also proficient in the Ten Recitations Sutra and had extensively studied various texts, those who sought the Dharma and inquired about the Way never left his seat empty.
In the first year of the Yuanjia era, in the third month, the emperor attended a banquet by the curved water and ordered Guan to compose a poem with the court officials.
Guan immediately presented his poem first, with clear and elegant words that suited the occasion.
Wang Sengda of Langya and He Shangzhi of Lujiang both expressed their sincerity with sincere words and formed a bond beyond the dust of the world.
He died in the Yuanjia period of the Liu Song Dynasty at the age of 71.

He wrote the Treatise on Distinguishing the Teachings, the Treatise on the Meaning of Sudden and Gradual Enlightenment, the Preface to the Ten Parables, and prefaces to various sutras, all of which are circulated in the world.
At that time, Seng Fu of Daochang Temple, originally from Liquan, specialized in the study of meaning and commented on the Suvará¹‡a-prabhÄsa-sÅ«tra.
There was also Fa Ye.
He was originally from Chang'an.
He was good at the Great and Small PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ Sutras and the Abhidharma-samuccaya.
He ate vegetarian food and restrained himself. Therefore, the Princess of Jinling built Nanlin Temple for him, and he later lived there.
Shi Huiyi, Shi Huiyi, whose surname was Liang, was from northern China.
He left home at a young age, and his style and demeanor were outstanding, with a strong and upright character.
He first studied in the Peng and Song areas and became well-versed in sutra meanings.
Later, he went to the capital and said:
In Jizhou, there was a monk named Facheng who told his disciple Puyuan before his death:
The spiritual deity of Songgao said, In Jiangdong there is General Liu who will receive the Mandate of Heaven. I will use thirty-two jades and a gold ingot as a token.
He then sent it to King Song.
King Song said to Yi,
This is an extraordinary auspicious sign, and it must be obtained by an extraordinary person.
If it is not obtained by the Dharma Master himself, I am afraid it will not be obtained.
Yi then went.
In the seventh month of the thirteenth year of Yixi in the Jin dynasty, he went to Songgao Mountain to search for it but did not find it.

He then single-mindedly burned incense and practiced the Way. After seven days and nights, he dreamed of an old man with a long beard who used a cane to lead Yi to the location of the jades and pointed out, saying,
They are under this stone.

The next morning, Yi traveled around the mountain and saw a place that was exactly as he had seen in the dream. Under the stone altar of the temple, he indeed found thirty-two large and small jades and a gold ingot.
This auspicious sign is detailed in the Song History.
After Huiyi returned to the capital, Emperor Wu of the Song treated him with even greater respect, and his treatment of him was even more profound when he ascended the throne.
In the first year of the Yongchu era of the Song dynasty, Cheqi Fan Tai established Qiyuan Temple. Since Huiyi's virtue was revered by the people, he was firmly requested to oversee the construction.
Huiyi, considering Fan Tai's utmost sincerity in faith, guided him on the rules and procedures.
At that time, people compared Huiyi to ÅšÄriputra and Fan Tai to AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada, thus the name Qiyuan was established.
Later, many monks from the Western Regions took refuge in this temple, either translating scriptures or teaching meditation methods.
In the first year of the Yuanjia era of the Song dynasty, Xu Xianzhi and Tan Daoci monopolized the power of the court.
Fan Tai had an expression of dissatisfaction and once vented his anger by scolding them.
Xu and Tan deeply resented this.
Those who heard about it all worried about Fan Tai's uncertain fate. Fan Tai also feared that he would be implicated in misfortune, so he asked Huiyi about the means of preserving his body.
Huiyi said:
Being loyal and obedient without fail, serving one's superiors, is why superiors and inferiors can be close to each other. What worries are worth being anxious about?
He then advised Tai to donate sixty mu of bamboo grove to the temple as a blessing for the netherworld.
Tai followed his advice and enjoyed the blessings until the end.
When Tai passed away, his third son Yan, following his father's treacherous ways, tried to take back the grove land, and finally seized it without giving it.
Yi held Tai's will, and the confusion and turmoil were evident to all.
Yi then moved to Wu Yi and lived with Hui Rui.
In the 21st year of the Yuanjia era of the Liu Song dynasty, he passed away at Wu Yi Temple at the age of 73.
Yan died a few years later.
Yan's younger brother Ye was later implicated in Kong Xixian's rebellion, and his clan was destroyed.
Later, there was another Shi Seng Rui at Jihuan Temple, who was good at the Three Treatises and was respected by Emperor Wen of the Liu Song dynasty.
6 Shi Daoyuan, Shi Daoyuan, whose surname was Kou, was not known where he was from. He became a monk and stayed at Dong'an Temple in the capital.
When young, he upheld the precepts and studied the doctrinal teachings. He was well-versed in various sutras and treatises.
But he concealed his light and virtues, and the world did not know him.
Later, when he lectured at Dong'an Temple, he analyzed the profound and penetrated the hidden, causing the long-accumulated blockages to melt like ice.
Thus, the students changed their views and unanimously followed his virtue.
Later, he moved to Pengcheng Temple.
Emperor Wen of the Liu Song Dynasty considered Daoyuan's conduct to be a model for others and ordered him to stay at the temple.
Later, he passed away at the age of seventy-eight.
Daoyuan's disciple Huilin, whose original surname was Liu, was from Qin Commandery.
He was good at various sutras, as well as the works of Zhuangzi and Laozi. He enjoyed witty banter and humor, and was good at composition, thus collecting ten scrolls of works.
But he was arrogant and self-important, and was quite self-congratulatory.
Yuan once visited Fu Liang, and Lin was already sitting there. When Yuan arrived, Lin did not pay respects to him.

Yuan became angry and showed it on his face. Liang then punished Lin with twenty blows.ğŸ”½Emperor Wen of the Liu Song dynasty greatly respected Lin and often invited him to sit on a special high seat. Yan Yanzhi often ridiculed this, and the emperor was displeased. Later, Lin wrote the Discourse on the White and Black, which contradicted Buddhist principles.
He Chengtian, the Prefect of Hengyang, was close to Lin and often praised him. He wrote the Discourse on Penetrating Nature, both of which were biased and criticized Buddhism.
Yan Yanzhi and Zong Bing refuted the two discourses, each with more than ten thousand words.
After Lin had slandered his own Dharma, he was expelled to Jiaozhou.
The world says that Master Yuan saw the hemp stars, and he is the one.
Shi Sengbi Shi Sengbi was originally from Wu. He had a simple and honest nature and a dignified demeanor.
When he was young, he traveled to Chang'an with Longguang Tangan and studied under Kumarajiva.
He cherished his strength and had deep thoughts. KumÄrajÄ«va especially admired him and let him participate in the translation work.
Later, he traveled to famous countries and observed the customs and culture everywhere.
At that time, there were requests for him to be the abbot of the temple, but he said:
The ultimate Way is not widely spread, and the pure wind is fading day by day. Without both concentration and wisdom, one cannot establish the Way.
Moreover, one should benefit according to conditions. How can one only benefit one temple?
Later, he lived in Chu and Ying for more than ten years.
He instructed and guided through the scriptures and precepts, greatly transforming the Jiangnan region.
The King of Hexi, Juqu Mengxun, admired his reputation from afar and sent envoys to pay respects and offer gifts continuously.
Later, he went to the capital and stayed at Pengcheng Temple. The emperor valued him and often invited him to lecture.
He passed away in the 19th year of the Yuanjia era of the Liu Song Dynasty, at the age of 78.
Shi Huijing, whose surname was Wang, was from Dong'e.
In his youth, he traveled to study in the regions of Yi and Luo, and later visited Xu and Yan.
His appearance was very dark, but his understanding was clear and far-reaching.
At that time, there was a monk named Dao Jing in Luo, who was also a great scholar of the time, and was on par with Zhi. However, his ears were very long, so people of the time said:
In Luo, there is one with long ears, and in Dong'a, one as black as ink.
If there are questions, he will answer them all. If there are answers, he will block them all.

Zhi's nature was originally open and understanding, and he was calm and had the power of thought. Whenever the Dharma wheel turned once, he would carry a thousand scrolls. Scholars from all over the country would gather without fail.

He recited the Lotus Sutra and the Small Treatise, annotated the Vimalakirti Sutra and the Sutra of Contemplation of the Buddha, wrote the Brief Record of Nirvana, the Purpose of the Great Treatise, and the Treatise on Understanding Life, as well as the epitaphs of various Dharma masters.
Many of them circulated in the north, but did not go over the river very much.
He died in the Yuanjia era of the Song Dynasty, at over sixty years old.
Shi Sengbao, a native of Jingzhao, studied under Master KumÄrajÄ«va in Guanzhong when he was young.
In the Yongchu period of the Liu Song Dynasty, he traveled to Beixu and entered Huangshan Monastery.
He then visited Masters Jing and Ding to further his studies.
He also held a seven-day Samantabhadra Repentance there.
On the seventh day, a white crane flew in and landed in front of Samantabhadra's seat. It stayed until the incense offering in the middle of the day was completed before leaving.
On the twenty-first day, in the evening, four people in yellow robes circled the pagoda several times and suddenly disappeared.
Since Sengbao had determination and virtue since young, and now with auspicious signs, he became even more diligent.
He recited ten thousand words of sutras every day and always bowed to the Buddha hundreds of times.
Later, he went to the capital in the east. It happened to be the time for a lecture at Jetavana Monastery. Dharma students gathered like clouds and scholars and laypeople filled the seats.
Since Sengbao had just arrived and no one knew him, he rode a donkey to watch.
His clothes were dirty and dusty, and the hall was already crowded, so he tethered his donkey outside the door.
When the lecturer finished presenting the topic, Bao was about to speak, but the Dharma master asked:
What is the name of the guest monk?
He replied:
My name is Bao.
He asked again:
What does it exhaust?
Bao answered:
The person on the high seat can also be Bao.
He then asked several questions, all of which the lecturer could not answer due to his lack of intellectual ability. The lecturer had no way to counter his words, so he retreated and stopped.
At that time, Wang Hong and Fan Tai heard about Bao's debates and admired his talent and thoughts. They invited him to have discussions with them.
He was then invited to stay at Qihuan Temple, where he lectured on various sutras, spreading the Dharma continuously.
Xie Lingyun of Chenjun heard about this and visited Bao. Upon meeting Bao's spiritual energy, he deeply admired and respected him.
Someone asked:
How is Mr. Xie?
Bao said:ğŸ”½He is a man of great talent and virtue, but he is not a true sage.
Lingyun has excess talent but insufficient knowledge, and he cannot avoid being implicated.
Bao once saw six robbers being led to execution on the road. Bao expounded the Dharma for them and encouraged them to recite Guanshiyin.
The group of robbers, facing imminent danger, recited with utmost sincerity.
Suddenly, the escort soldiers became heavily intoxicated from drinking, and the robbers were able to untie their shackles and escape.
He died during the Yuanjia period of the Song dynasty.

At that time, there was also Shi Fahu at Waguan Temple, who was also proficient in various treatises and gained fame at that time. He was respected by Emperor Gao of the Song, who ordered him to be the leader of the monks.
Shi Sengquan, whose surname was Zhang, was a person from Haiyang in Liaoxi.
In his youth, he traveled to Yan and Qi, where he studied various non-Buddhist classics. At the age of twenty, he left home to become a monk.
He then delved into the Tripiá¹­aka and became the leader of those who studied in the north.
Later, he crossed the Yangtze River and stayed in the capital, where he held grand lectures, spreading the Dharma to the south of the river.
Zhang Gong of Wu Commandery invited him back to Wu to lecture, and the people of Gussu all admired his virtue and turned to him.
He first stayed at Xianju Temple and later rested at Huqiu Mountain.
Before, at Huanglong State, he had made a sixteen-foot golden statue. After entering Wu, he made another human-sized golden statue and placed it in the Eastern Temple on Huqiu Mountain.
Xuan was by nature fond of giving generously, providing for the poor and needy. He was pure and upright, living frugally without extra adornments.
Later, Meng Yi of Pingchang established Fangxian Temple in Yuhang and invited Xuan to reside there.
He led the assembly in diligent practice, with meditation and worship never ceasing. His study was so intense that he eventually went blind.
Yet he redoubled his efforts and did not neglect teaching.
Zhang Chang, Zhang Fu of Wuguo, Dai Yong, Dai Bo of Qiaoguo all admired his virtue, befriended him, and revered him as their teacher.
Later, Xuan temporarily visited Linan County and stayed at the home of Dong Gongcao, who was a faithful disciple.
After a short stay, he encountered a serious illness, but he always saw the image he had made coming to the western wall, and he also saw celestial boys all coming to attend to his illness.
His disciple Falang dreamed of a platform, with several people carrying it, and asked where it was going. They replied, We are welcoming Dharma Master Xuan.
The next morning, he indeed passed away.
The county magistrate Ruan Shangzhi had him buried to the right of the tomb of Guowen Juzhi on Mount Baitu, to emulate Liang Hong's association with Yao Li.
The special envoy Wang Yu and the lofty scholar Dai Yong went to Xuan's tomb and erected a stele, with Tang Si Xian composing the text and Zhang Fu writing the epitaph.
Shi Tangan, Shi Tangan, with the surname Zhao, was a person from Jizhou.
He left home at a young age and served Zhu Dazu as his teacher.
He ate vegetarian food, wore coarse clothes, and was strict in observing the precepts. He studied various sutras and was also good at philosophical reasoning.
He heard that Master KumÄrajÄ«va was in Guanzhong, so he took his staff and followed to study.
KumÄrajÄ«va often called him a person who could memorize after one hearing.
Later, he traveled around spreading the teachings, reaching from Jingzhou to Xin Temple in Jiangling.
When he reached the age of sixty, his practice became even more pure. He always wished to be reborn in the Pure Land to see AmitÄbha.
Later, his disciple Sengji took leave to go to Shangming, and Jian said:
Your departure is excellent, but I'm afraid we will not meet again.
He then carefully wrote a letter of entrustment.
That night, he discussed impermanence with the elders, speaking very earnestly.
After midnight, everyone returned to their rooms, but Jian stayed behind walking in the corridor.
At three o'clock in the morning, the novice monk Sengyuan asked him to return to his room, and Jian said:
You may just sleep. You don't need to come again.

The next morning, his disciple Huiyan came to pay his respects as usual. He saw Jian sitting upright with his palms joined, but he was not speaking. When they approached to examine him, they realized he had already passed away.
His body became soft and fragrant, twice as usual, and he was laid to rest in this manner.
He was 70 years old.
Zhang Bian of Wu Prefecture wrote a biography and eulogy for him, the eulogy says:
Wearing lychee to show fragrance, holding jade to symbolize purity.
The Dharma Master Hunhun, neither turbid nor clear.
Shining in the early years, flourishing in the later years.
The spirit wanders and the wisdom goes, how can it be a real farewell?

At that time, there were also Shi Daohui, Shi Huikan of Beizhou, Shi Huigong of Dongzhou, Shi Tanhong of Huainan, Shi Daoguang of Dongyuan Mountain, and Shi Daoguang of Hongnong, all of whom wished to be reborn in the Pure Land, and had auspicious signs at the end of their lives.
Shi Huian, Shi Huian, it is unknown who he was.
He ate vegetarian food, was diligent and austere, studied and understood the sutras and their meanings, and was also able to speak well. He was also known for his strict observance of precepts.
He recited over 400,000 words of sutras.
He stayed at Lingyun Temple on Mount Lu, and his disciples gathered like clouds, coming from a thousand miles away.
He always carried a staff, saying it was given by a monk from the Western Regions.
The staff emitted a bright light and also had a faint fragrance.
There were Sanskrit letters on it, which no one could read.
Later, he entered the pass and went to where KumÄrajÄ«va was, carrying the staff with him.
When KumÄrajÄ«va saw the staff, he was surprised and said:
How did this staff end up here?
He then translated the letters, saying:
Originally born in the ÅšÄla Grove of India, in the south, during chaos, the grass was entrusted to flourish. Later, when KumÄrajÄ«va arrived, the Way and teachings prospered.
Later, An gave the staff as a gift to the foreign monk PÄÅ›Äá¹‡a, who took it back to the Western Regions.
An died in the mountains during the Yuanjia era of the Song dynasty.
Shi Tanwucheng, whose surname was Ma, was a person from Fufeng.

His family migrated to live in Huanglong to avoid persecution. At the age of thirteen, he left home to become a monk. His conduct was pure and upright, and his spiritual understanding was extraordinary. Before he was fully ordained, he was already proficient in the scriptures.
He heard that KumÄrajÄ«va was in Guanzhong and followed him, carrying his books.
When he arrived, he met KumÄrajÄ«va, who asked:
Why has the novice come from afar?
He replied:
I have come to study the Way.
KumÄrajÄ«va greatly welcomed him.
Thus he stayed to study, and his wisdom and practice became increasingly profound.
Yao Xing said to Sengrui:
Ma Jilong is erudite and highly regarded, and has always been arrogant in the world. The Dharma Master should not be like this.
He replied:
By subduing the mind with the Way, I eliminate this fault.
Yao Xing greatly admired him, and his offerings were very generous.
As Yao Xing's reign was about to end and Guanzhong was in turmoil, Sengrui then stayed at Zhong Temple in Huainan.
He constantly lectured on the Nirvana Sutra and the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ Sutra, with over two hundred students studying under him.
He discussed the truth of reality with Yan Yanzhi and He Shangzhi, going back and forth all morning.
Sengrui then wrote the Treatise on the Truth of Reality.
He also wrote the Treatise on Clarifying Gradualism.
He died in the Yuanjia period of the Liu Song Dynasty at the age of 64.
At that time, Zhong Temple also had Tan Jing, who was a classmate and equal in fame to Cheng, and was respected by Liu Yikeng, the King of Linchuan of the Liu Song Dynasty.
Shi Seng Han, Shi Seng Han, was not known where he was from.
He loved learning since he was young, and was devoted to classics and history, as well as astronomy and mathematics.
When he grew up, he understood Buddhist principles, was proficient in number theory, and was especially good at the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra. He always lectured on it without stopping.
In the seventh year of the Yuanjia period, Tao Zhongzu, the Prefect of Xin Xing, established Lingwei Temple.
Admiring Seng Han's demeanor and conduct, he invited him to live there.
Seng Han encouraged the assembly to be pure and prudent, without neglecting the three karmas.
Later, he traveled west to Linyang to promote the true Dharma. The monks and laypeople in Jiangzuo followed him like a forest.
At that time, Peng Cheng, the Prefect of Rencheng, wrote the Treatise on the Non-existence of the Three Times. Seng Han then wrote the Treatise on the Immortality of the Spirit to counter it.
So that those who see and hear it will not fail to be revived when about to fall.

He also wrote the Treatise on the Perfect Mirror of Holy Wisdom, the Treatise on Non-arising, the Treatise on the Dharma Body, the Treatise on Karmic Retribution, and the Treatise on the Lotus SÅ«tra, which are all transmitted in the world.
After a while, he traveled south to Jiujiang and greatly expounded the sÅ«tras and Dharma.
Yan Jun of Langya was then the military aide to the governor of Nan Zhonglang, stationed in Xunyang, and he highly regarded and valued Huiyan. Whenever he visited, they would stay together all day.
Huiyan once secretly told Yan Jun:
If the prophecies are not false, there will soon be misfortune and chaos in the capital.
The true person who corresponds with the omens is none other than Your Lordship. You should keep this in mind.
Soon after, the evil plotters incited a rebellion, and the Son of Heaven ascended the throne. It was indeed as he had said.
Later, he was in good health and without illness. He suddenly told the assembly to take leave of him.
By the next morning, he had already passed away peacefully. People at that time called him one who knew his life span.
At that time, there was also Shi Daohan, who also had achievements in learning and understanding, and wrote the Shiyi Shi Lun (Ten Discourses on Distinguishing Differences).
Shi Sengche, whose surname was Wang, was originally from Jin Yang, Taiyuan.
He was orphaned at an early age, and he and his brother lived in Xiangyang.
When Sengche was sixteen years old, he went to Mount Lu to visit Master Huiyuan.
Huiyuan saw him and thought he was extraordinary, so he asked:
Do you have the intention to leave the household life?
Sengche replied:
Leaving the dust and worldly affairs has always been my original intention.
Only a craftsman can truly understand the importance of a plumb line and a scale.
Huiyuan said:
If you can enter the Way, you will attain the Dharma gate of fearlessness.
Thus, Sengche shaved his head and became a monk, following Huiyuan to study.
He studied all the sutras, and was especially proficient in the Prajnaparamita.
In his spare time from inquiring about the Way, he also wrote essays and poems, and whenever he put pen to paper, the chapters and verses were spontaneously completed.
Once, he climbed a pine tree to the south of the mountain and whistled. Then, the clear wind gathered from afar, and various birds sang in harmony. He had a transcendent and outstanding air.
He withdrew and asked Huijian:
The Vinaya rules prohibit stringed instruments, and the precepts forbid singing and dancing.
Can chanting and whistling be considered as such?
Huijian said:
In terms of distraction, they are all against the Dharma.
Therefore, he stopped.
When he was twenty-four years old, Huijian ordered him to lecture on the Small Sutra.
At that time, his peers did not approve of it.
But when he ascended the seat, his words and phrases were clearly analyzed, and the listeners could not defeat him.
Huijian said to him:
The formidable opponents did not spare any effort. Your city's defenses are strict, and the attackers will lose their troops.
To be able to do this in return is truly not easy.
Therefore, the disciples pushed and served him.
After Huijian passed away, he traveled south to Jingzhou and stayed at Wuceng Temple inside Jiangling City. Later, he moved to Pipa Temple.
Prince of Pengcheng Yikang, Yitong Xiao Sihua, and others all received precepts from him.
He was invited to vegetarian feasts, where he personally served the food.
He died in the 29th year of the Yuanjia era of the Liu Song Dynasty at the age of 70.
The Governor of Nanqiao, Prince Liu Yixuan, built a tomb for him.

At that time, Shi Sengzhuang of Shangming in Jingzhou was also good at the Nirvana Sutra and various theories. In the beginning of the Xiao Wu era of the Liu Song Dynasty, he was ordered to go to the capital but declined due to illness.
Shi Tanti, Shi Tanti, whose surname was Kang, was from Kangju. During the reign of Emperor Ling of the Han Dynasty, he moved to China. At the end of Emperor Xian's reign, he moved to Wuxing.
Tanti's father, Rong, was once the Governor of Jizhou.

His mother, Huang, took a nap and dreamed of a monk who called Huang mother and entrusted her with a yak-tail whisk and two iron bookends. When she woke up, she saw that the two items were still there. She then became pregnant and gave birth to Tanti.
When Di was five years old, his mother showed him the fly whisk and other items.
Di said:
They were sent by the King of Qin.
His mother said:
Where did you put them?
He replied:
I don't remember.
At the age of ten, he left home. He did not learn from a teacher, but his understanding arose naturally.
Later, he followed his father to Fan and Deng, where he met the monk Lu from Guanzhong. He suddenly called out to Lu by name.
Lu said:
Why does the young boy call out the name of an elder?
Di said:
Just now, he suddenly said 'Ah Shang', which is the novice Di, who was gathering vegetables for the monks and was injured by a wild boar. I didn't realize I had spoken out loud.
Lu had been a disciple of Dharma Master Hongjue and had been gathering vegetables for the monks when he was injured by a wild boar.
Lu did not remember this at first, so he went to Di's father.
Di's father told him the whole story and showed him the bookends, fly whisk, and other items.
Zhi then realized and wept, saying:
This is my late teacher, Dharma Master Hongjue.
When Master [Hongjue] lectured on the Lotus Sutra for Yao Chang, I was the chief lecturer. Yao Chang gave Master [Hongjue] two things, which are now here.
Reckoning the date of Hongjue's death, it was precisely the day he entrusted the items. Remembering the incident of picking vegetables, he felt even deeper sadness and admiration.

Later, Di traveled and studied various scriptures, memorizing what he encountered. Later, he entered Huqiu Temple in Wu and lectured on the Rites, the Book of Changes, and the Spring and Autumn Annals each seven times, and on the Lotus Sutra, the Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra, and the Vimalakirti Sutra each fifteen times.
He was also good at writing prose and poetry, and collected them into six fascicles, which are also circulated in the world.
He loved forests and springs by nature. Later, he returned to Wuxing and entered the old Zhang Kunlun Mountain. He lived in seclusion by a stream for more than twenty years.
He died in his mountain hut in the late Yuanjia era of the Song dynasty, at over sixty years old.
17 Shi Sengdao, Shi Sengdao, a person from Jingzhao.
At the age of ten, he left home to follow a teacher to receive teachings. The teacher gave him the Sutra of Avalokitesvara.
After reading it, he asked the teacher:
How many scrolls does this sutra have?
The teacher wanted to test him, so he said:
There are only this many.
Sengdao said:
It begins with 'At that time, Inexhaustible Intention,' so I know there must have been events before that.
The teacher greatly admired him and gave him a copy of the Lotus Sutra.
Then, day and night, he read and roughly understood the text and meaning.
Poor and without oil lamps, he always collected firewood to light himself.
By the age of eighteen, he had read widely and extensively.
His bearing was heroic and courageous, his spiritual capacity was outstanding, his appearance was square and elegant, and his movements were unobtrusive.
Sengrui saw him and admired him, asking:
What do you wish to do in the Buddha's teachings?
Sengdao said:
I would like you to be the main lecturer for the Dharma master.
Huiyuan said:
You are about to be the Dharma master for ten thousand people, how can you be willing to be a small teacher?
Until he received full ordination, his understanding became more profound, and he mastered meditation, precepts, sutras, and treatises, all by himself.
Yao Xing admired his virtue and industry, befriended him, and loved him.
When he entered the temple to visit, he would share the same carriage on the way back to the palace.
When KumÄrajÄ«va translated sutras and treatises, he participated in the discussion and finalized them.

Since Daodu already had a profound understanding, and he encountered the flourishing collection in Guanzhong, he then planned and collected the various scriptures, extensively adopting both true and secular teachings. He composed commentaries on the Satyasiddhi-Å›Ästra and the Three Treatises, as well as the Treatise on the Two Truths of Emptiness and Existence, etc.

Later, when Emperor Gaozu of the Liu Song dynasty attacked Chang'an in the west, he captured the puppet ruler and thoroughly cleared the Guanzhong region. Since he had long admired Daodu's reputation, he wanted to meet him. He said to Daodu:
I have long admired you, but why have you been stranded in a foreign land?
He replied:
Your Excellency has pacified the Nine Regions, and the imperial chariot resounds on the Yellow River and Luo River. It would be excellent to meet at this time.
When Gaozu turned his chariot and returned east, he left his son, the Marquis of Guiyang, Yizhen, to garrison Guanzhong. As he was about to depart, he said to Tandu:
My son is young and left behind to garrison. I wish that the Dharma Master could always keep him in mind.
Later, Yizhen was besieged by the Western Barbarians, the Bubub Helian, and escaped from Guanzhong.
On the way, he was disturbed and defeated. The ugly barbarians pursued him with a chasing army that was about to catch up.
Tandu led several hundred disciples to block the middle of the road and said to the chasing army:
Liu Gong entrusted this son to me. I will now use death to send him off. We will not meet. You need not chase after us.
The group of barbarians was awed by his spiritual air and thus turned back.
Yizhen fled and hid in the grass. In the midst of this, Duan Hong, a general of the central army, finally managed to escape. This was all due to Tandu's power.
Emperor Gaozu was moved by this and ordered his sons and nephews to study under him.
Later, he established a temple in Shouchun, which was East Mountain Temple.
He often lectured on sutras and treatises, with over a thousand people studying under him.
When the barbarians suddenly destroyed Buddhism, several hundred monks took refuge with him, and he provided them with clothing and food.
For those who died at the hands of the barbarians, he held memorial services and wept tears of sorrow for them.

When Emperor Xiaowu ascended the throne, he sent envoys to invite him. Dao immediately responded to the imperial decree and stayed at Zhongxing Temple in the capital. The imperial carriage descended, and he personally came out to greet him.
Dao, in the first year of Xiaojian, when the three bonds were restored, was moved by the events and felt grief beyond words.
The emperor also choked with sobs for a long time. He then ordered Dao to lecture on the Vimalakirti Sutra at Waguan Temple.
The emperor personally attended, and the officials were required to gather.
Dao ascended the high seat and said:

In the past, the Buddha was born in the royal palace and manifested his nirvana under the twin trees. Since then, more than a thousand years have passed, and the pure source has long disappeared, with the decadent wind not following.
The Buddha's garden is in ruins, and the deer park is overgrown.
The ninety-five kinds of non-Buddhist paths take going down as ascending;
The beings in the three realms take the burning house as the pure land.
How could they know that the sages above are weeping and the great beings are in despair?
Thus, he secretly shed tears, and the four assemblies changed their expressions.
He also said to the Emperor:
In protecting the Dharma and propagating the Way, nothing surpasses the emperor.

If Your Majesty can operate the mind of the four equalities, sympathize with the weak, and encourage goodness, then these pebbles, gravel, and rubble will become the palace of the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Pleasures.
The Emperor praised him for a long time.
Those who were present were all delighted.
Later, he took leave to return to Shouchun and passed away at Shijian, at the age of ninety-six.
At that time, there was also a monk named Sengyin, who was also a famous master of the time, and he was on par with Daojin.
Someone asked:
Which is better, the Dharma Master or Master Dao?
He replied:
I and Sengdao both studied under Master She. According to the Confucian school, Master Dao is in the inner chamber, while I can ascend the hall.
Sengdao had disciples such as Sengwei and Sengyin, who were both good at the Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra.
Shi Daowang, Shi Daowang, whose surname was Pan, was a person from Chang'an.
At a young age, he followed his uncle in the capital. At the age of thirteen, he left home to become a monk under Master Yuan of Mount Lu.
He studied the sutras and precepts, and was especially good at the Nirvana Sutra. He ate vegetarian food for over ten years.
Once, while traveling through Liangzhou, he was surrounded by Qiang bandits on the road and almost lost his robes and alms bowl.
Daowang and his disciples, several people, vowed to single-mindedly recite Guanshiyin.
After a while, they felt as if clouds were covering their bodies.
The bandits searched for them but could not find them, and thus they were spared.
Later, he heard that Dharma Master Xuan Gao of Hejian had profound and vast Chan and wisdom, and wanted to go and follow him.
On the way, he encountered the difficulties of the Tujue people, and in the end, he was unable to go. Thus, he returned to Chengdu.
The scholar Fei Wenxuan first studied under him. He then established a temple northwest of the city, named Jihua.
His teachings spread in the Bashu region, and his reputation reached the court and the countryside.
Shen Tan, the Prefect of Liangzhou, had an old friendship with Wang. Later, Shen Tan became ill, and Wang was about to go and visit him, and he also wanted to stay there.
Fei Wenxuan then wrote a letter to Prefect Zhang Yue, saying:
Dharma Master Dao Wang has pure knowledge and conduct, and his demeanor is increasingly lofty. He stands out from the crowd, and it is difficult to pull him out.
Recently, I heard that Liangzhou sent an invitation, and I heard that the imperial decree allowed him to leave. The discussions in the entire region all say it is not appropriate.

The monks and nuns in the border regions of the state number in the thousands. The support of Chan and precepts is one of the things they rely on. How can water lose its pearls, or mountains lose their jade?
I hope you will consider the sincerity of the nine common people and allow the four groups to have a basis.
Yue then earnestly requested him to stay, and he finally did not leave.
When Yue returned to the capital, he told Emperor Xiaowu of the Song in detail about Wang's virtue and conduct.
The emperor immediately issued an edict inviting him to be the abbot of Zhongxing Temple.
Wang then took advantage of Yue's illness and firmly declined, thus escaping.
Thereupon, he excused himself from illness, lowered his curtain, and completely stopped looking at the human world.
Later, when Liu Si was in charge of the state, he held a great Dharma assembly and invited Wang to lecture. He then responded to the invitation. Someone asked:
The Dharma master always vowed to keep to seclusion. Why do you violate your principles?
He replied:
Liu Gong has a deep faith and is about to rely on the great Dharma. How can I refuse a little trouble?
Previously, people in the gorge often saw divine light shining at night on the side of the rocky cliff.
In the great Ming dynasty, Si Khao requested Wang to build a temple at the place of light.
He carved an image on the cliff and built rooms on the dangerous terrain.
Those who passed by looked up to it and all gave rise to pure thoughts.
Later, Wang Jingmao invited him to live in Wudan Temple as the head monk. He encouraged the assembly to be pure and careful, and both laypeople and monks took refuge in him.
In the first year of the Taishi era of the Song dynasty, he passed away in his residence. He instructed to cremate his body.
Liu Si Khao built a stupa for him to the right of the temple gate of Wudan Temple.
In the first year of the Jinghe era, Xiao Huikai was the governor of Chengdu in the west. He admired Wang's high reputation and wanted to discuss the Way with him.
When he was halfway there, he heard that Wang had already passed away. He sighed and said:
It's a pity, I didn't get to meet that person.
What's the point of Wen Ju chasing after Kang Cheng?
The contemporaries lamented him like this.
At that time, Shi Puming of Jiangyang Temple in Shu Prefecture and Shi Daoguang of Changle Temple, both had lofty moral integrity and were highly regarded for their precepts.
They abstained from meat, recited sutras, and practiced asceticism, attaining spiritual powers.
Daoguang was well-versed in both Buddhist and non-Buddhist teachings, and was especially eloquent. Zhang Yu of Wu Prefecture invited him to be his precept teacher.
Shi Huijing, with the surname Shao, was a person from Yuhang, Wuxing.
He lived in poverty but upheld his principles, practicing asceticism with utmost sincerity, and had an outstanding appearance with dignified demeanor.
He first studied at Mount Lu and later returned to the capital to further his studies.
He was well-versed in both Buddhist and non-Buddhist teachings, and was particularly skilled in the Nirvana Sutra.
He initially stayed at Zhicheng Temple, admired by Yan Yanzhi and He Shangzhi.
Yan Yanzhi often sighed:
Only Huijing is like a jade from Mount Jing.ğŸ”½When his son Zun was appointed to the post in Dongzhou, he took Huijing with him and stayed at Tianzhu Temple.
During the Daming era, he moved to Fahua Terrace in Shan.
Later, he rested at Dongyang Mountain, traveling everywhere, and made it his duty to spread the Dharma.
As he passed the age of knowing his life span, his determination became even stronger.
He died in the Taishi era of the Song dynasty, at the age of fifty-eight.
The literary works he composed were collected into ten fascicles.
Shi Famin, Shi Famin, a northerner, admired the Way from a young age and was devoted to scriptures. At eighteen, he left home and traveled to various states, observing customs and enjoying the Way.
He was well-versed in the Prajnaparamita, various theories, and sutras and vinaya.
Later, he rested at Wuceng Temple in Jiangxia Prefecture.
At that time, Shamen Sengchang established a pagoda inside Jiangling City.
Prefect Xie Hui wanted to destroy it. Famin heard about it and went to advise Hui.
Hui's intention did not stop, so Famin then hid his traces at Luoshan in Changsha, not coming out for the rest of his life.
Hui then led his troops to the temple, generously bestowing wine and meat, and with the sound of drums and the majesty of authority, he cut and hacked the statues.
Suddenly, clouds and fog darkened the sky, and wind and dust arose in the four directions. Hui was frightened and ran away. Later, he was executed for rebellion.
The members of the group, Ding Facheng and Shi Sengshuang, became afflicted with leprosy, and many others violated the law and died.
Min then wrote the Discourse on Manifestation and Verification to clarify cause and effect, and annotated the Great Way Ground Sutra.
Later, he died in the mountains at the age of eighty-three. His disciple Seng Daolç«‹ erected a stele to praise his virtues.

At that time, at Linghua Temple in Shixing Prefecture, there was a monk named Seng Zong, who was also well-versed in sutras and treatises. He wrote the Dharma Nature and Enlightened Nature discourses.

Later, he passed away in Danyang at over seventy years old.
At that time, there was also Shi Sengyao, who was originally from Shangdang. He was good at the Nirvana Sutra and was respected by Zhang Cheng.
Shi Daowen, whose surname was Huangfu, was a person from Chaona in Anding, the descendant of Gao Shi Numi.
In his youth, he loved the qin and calligraphy, and was known for his filial piety towards his parents.

Later, he traveled to Chang'an and studied under KumÄrajÄ«va again.
During the Yuanjia period, he returned to stay at Tankou Temple in Xiangyang.

At that time, Zhang Shao of Wu State was stationed in Xiangyang, and his son Fu followed him. After Fu attended Master Wen's lectures and returned, Zhang Shao asked him about Master Wen. Fu said:
His understanding of principles is sufficient to analyze the subtle, but his mind of the Way is difficult to fathom.

On the eighth day of the tenth month in the fourth year of the Daming era of Empress Dowager Zuo, the image of Samantabhadra was completed. A vegetarian feast was held in the Chan Cloister of Zhongxing, and two hundred monks were invited. Their names were listed together, and the number of people was fixed.
At that time, the temple was newly built, and the guards were very strict.
Suddenly, a monk came late and sat down. His demeanor was elegant, and everyone in the hall looked at him.
He spoke with the feast host for over a hundred words, and suddenly he disappeared.
The gatekeeper checked and said that he did not see him come or go, and the crowd then realized that he was a divine person.
At that time, Wen was the head of the monks, so he wrote a report to Moling, saying:
The empress dowager's wisdom is profound and bright, and her sagely virtue is deeply felt. She purifies her thoughts in the pure field and investigates the ultimate realm.
She has indeed spread her fame within the palace, and her affairs are empty above the Buddhist realm.
She then began to melt and forge, and to write and create divine flowers. She modeled and created Samantabhadra, and the magnificent image arrived.
The treasures are as abundant as the universe, and the wonders are as exquisite as the heavens.
The vegetarian feast and lectures were held until the eighth day of this month.ğŸ”½The offerings are limited, and the guest list was already set.
The seats were arranged in order, with the number neither exceeding nor decreasing.
When the sutra recitation reached halfway, the sun was at its zenith.
Suddenly, an unusual monk was seen sitting in the middle of the assembly.
His appearance was dignified, and his bearing was outstanding.
The entire assembly was shocked and amazed, but no one recognized him.
The host of the vegetarian feast asked:
What is the name of the Venerable?
He replied:
My name is Huiming.
Which temple do you reside in?
He answered:
I come from Tian'an.
As soon as he finished speaking, he suddenly disappeared.
The entire assembly was awestruck and filled with reverence.
They considered it a bright auspicious sign, a manifestation of the profound response.
Purple mountains can be seen, and the Flower Treasury World is not far away.
I have heard that when sincerity moves the heavens, the sun can be made to revert and the stars to change their positions.
The mind of purity pursued it, and the stone opened to reveal a spring.
Moreover, the imperial virtue encompasses the operation of the universe, and the imperial achievements are vast and pervasive.
Compassion penetrates the distant heavens, and principles are clear beyond the unseen world.
Therefore, the most noble and virtuous people mark the great and bright dynasty;
The wondrous body is inspired, and personally sees the dragon ascending to the palace.
It is as if the imperial wisdom illuminates the ocean's edge, and the bright flowers are like the sun and moon. Therefore, Wisdom and Light is used as the person's name.
Continuing the heavenly establishment of the dynasty, it is a model for eternity. Therefore, Heavenly Peace is used as the name of the temple.
The divine foundation is increasingly distant, and the Way and governance are now clear.
The nine regions are all at peace, and the myriad borders are in harmony.
I respectfully list the words and report to the county, in order to proclaim the heavenly blessings.
County is the same as prefecture.
At that time, the Prefect of Jingzhao, Kong Lingfu, reported the matter to the court. The edict then changed the meditation room to Tian'an Temple, using it as a symbol of auspiciousness.
Later, Wen was repeatedly appointed to lecture.
The guests who received his teachings were filled with gratitude, and he diligently guided others, often experiencing spiritual wonders.
The emperor was delighted and bestowed 500,000 coins on him.
People of the time said:
The emperor emptied his treasury, Master Wen set the example.

Shi Tanbin, Shi Tanbin, whose surname was Su, was a native of Nanyang.

At night he dreamed of a divine person who said to Bin:
The doubts you have about the teachings, travel around to resolve them yourself.
Thus, he shook his staff and carried his robe, asking for the Way in different lands.
When he first arrived in the capital, he went to Wu County.
He met Sengye lecturing on the Ten Recitations Vinaya, and after listening for a short time, he deeply understood and penetrated it.

The Prince of Jianping of the Song Dynasty, Jing Su, also consulted him for precepts and standards.
In the Yuanhui period of the Liu Song dynasty, he passed away at Zhuangyan Temple at the age of 67.
At that time, Zhuangyan also had Tanji and Tansong, who were both respected for their academic achievements and literary talent.

Shi Huiliang, whose surname was Jiang, was originally named Xianliang, and was a disciple of Master Jing of Dong'e.
He had a clear reputation since young, and people of the time called Jing the Great Master and Liang the Little Master.
Although he was not yet as accomplished in age and virtue, his conduct and demeanor continued the legacy.
Later, he established a temple in Linzi and lectured on the Lotus Sutra, the Larger and Smaller PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ Sutras, the Ten Grounds Sutra, and others.
